terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Tasmanian mountains. Significant elevation with mountain scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional Tasmanian event. Mountainous terrain with very difficult access, high costs, and regional field.

biased_opinion.summary: Devils Cardigan is a regional event in Tasmania—mountainous terrain with significant elevation. The Tasmanian mountains are impressive and organization is solid, but the very difficult/expensive access and regional field keep it firmly in Tier 3.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A scenic Tasmanian mountain gravel race. Worth it for adventure seekers with big budgets. Not practical for most international riders.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you have a big budget and want a Tasmania experience—maybe. For most riders—there are better options.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better value: regional gravel races. For similar Australian terrain: Gravelista.

logistics.airport: Hobart (HBA) or Launceston (LST) varies by location
logistics.lodging_strategy: Tasmania has limited lodging options. Plan ahead.
logistics.food: Tasmania has good dining options. Stock nutrition.

logistics.explanation: Derby requires flying to Tasmania, then driving to a town most Australians couldn't find on a map. Nicole Frain won the women's race "convinced at the last minute with a borrowed mountain bike," highlighting the logistical scrambling required. Basic race information like entry fees, field size limits, and packet pickup details remain mysteriously unavailable even after hosting nationals and joining UCI World Series.

length.explanation: The 106km course with 2,300m of climbing delivers serious distance that breaks riders down systematically. Elite winner Brendan Johnston needed 3:24:12 to complete the course, while women's winner Talia Appleton required 4:03:15. Scott Mattern created his own "150km XL Cardigan" by combining both distance options, noting "Most of the ride is now lost in a blur of bar-chewing climbs and bone-rattling descents." Longer than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

technicality.explanation: The gravel "isn't what riders would normally call 'champagne gravel'" but rather "more like a rocky mountain bike trail in most parts." Max Hobson observed that "for lighter and skinnier set-ups, this first descent has them rattled – quite literally rattled." Dead Horse Hill Descent became a race-defining technical challenge that caused multiple elite riders to puncture on the rough, rocky terrain. Similar technical demands to Gravel Worlds.

elevation.explanation: Three major climbs define the suffering: 8.3km Mutual Valley at 4.2%, Ralph Falls spanning 10.7km at 5% with 16% maximum gradient, and the aptly named "Un-named Climb of Hell" at 8.1% average over 3.5km. The elite men's field hit threshold territory for the first 15 minutes on Mutual Valley alone. A final kicker within 10km punishes riders when legs are already destroyed. More climbing than SBT GRVL at the same score.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 42°F and lows of 34°F, with a 65% chance of rain on any given day, and gusts reaching 28 mph. Tasmania's winter conditions create annual weather roulette. "Year one had near-freezing conditions with bouts of rain and sleet-like scuds. Year two served up near gale-force winds." The 2023 race featured torrential rain that "muddied the course" significantly. Scott Mattern warns that "layers against wind rain and cold are a must on each and every trip." More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Derby sits at modest Tasmanian elevations without serious altitude effects, though pre-race chatter included concerns about "snow above 800m." The 2,300m of total climbing comes through sustained elevation changes rather than high-altitude challenges. Maximum elevations remain within Tasmania's moderate mountain ranges where weather exposure matters more than thin air. Modest altitude compared to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

adventure.explanation: Scott Mattern's single-track section became "one steady trickling creek" after heavy rain, forcing riders to navigate what should have been highlights as "challenging and gritty grind." His night riding through fog left him with lights that "refracted by the fog, and hindered rather than helped my visibility." The 87% gravel course through remote Tasmanian wilderness delivers isolation where mechanical failures have consequences.

prestige.explanation: Derby, Tasmania isn't the center of the gravel universe, and the UCI Gravel World Series inclusion in 2025 feels more like a participation trophy than earned status. Sure, it hosted AusCycling Gravel Nationals in 2023 and 2024, but that's like being the tallest kid in elementary school. The race website mentions 'the gravel scene taking on the world' - cute aspirational marketing, but prestige comes from decades of breaking spirits, not press releases.

race_quality.explanation: The 2024 race delivered "a record breaking super fast race" with elite fields starting separately and systematic race development. Brendan Johnston's winning attack on Ralph Falls Climb "approximately 35km into the race" demonstrated tactical racing opportunities. Course photography by Kristina Vackova and Beardy McBeard adds professional documentation, though basic logistical information gaps remain.

experience.explanation: Justin Morris was "unrecognisable at the finish line but his grin from ear to ear was plain to see." The combination of technical terrain, weather exposure, and remote wilderness creates the type of earned suffering that transforms into stories. Scott Mattern captured brief "golden moments of noticing the light rays that glinted through the trees and the fog" between the systematic destruction.

community.explanation: Post-race, "everyone flocked to the Dorsett Hotel in Derby for a well-deserved and eagerly anticipated banger of a dinner, chat with mates and another beer (or 3) by the fire." The North East Lions Club cooks "145 Litres of Soup" annually for depleted racers. Winners receive handmade wooly cardigan trophies and potato sacks, creating distinctly Tasmanian celebration traditions.

field_depth.explanation: The 2025 elite men's field featured "47 quality riders from all over Australia" while women's elite had 13 starters. Remote Tasmanian location naturally limits international participation despite UCI status. Elite talent like Tiffany Cromwell and race-winning performances show quality depth within the Australian gravel scene, but global representation remains constrained by geography. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100.

value.explanation: Winners receive "a sack of potatoes and handmade wooly cardigan winners trophy" plus post-race craft beer and local pub dinner included. The North East Lions Club provides 145 liters of soup and sausages to all finishers. Professional race photography and separate elite starts add value, though entry fees and complete package details remain undisclosed.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $150-250 AUD. Derby, Tasmania - you're looking at international flights, domestic connections, rental car, and accommodation in a tourist area that knows you're trapped. The website mentions accommodation partners but provides zero actual details or pricing, which usually means expensive and limited. Getting gear there and back adds another layer of logistical cost most riders don't calculate until too late. More expensive than Atlas Mountain Race.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

videos.title: 2024 Devils Cardigan Elite Womens Race - AusCycling Gravel National Championship.
videos.description:
The 2024 AusCycling Gravel National Championships were held on June 22, at the 4th Edition of the Devils Cardigan Gravel Race in Derby, Tasmania. 

It was  day of hot racing despite the frosty winter start, the 106 km Championship course delievered 2400m of elevation with a spicey range of gravel surfaces. 

Congratulations to all that took part in this years event and thank you to Jasper Da Seymour for capturing the action.

videos.title: The Devils Cardigan 2025 - UCI Gravel World Series
videos.description:
In 2025, the Devils Cardigan Gravel Race in Tasmania joined the @UCIGravelWorldSeries and brought our glorious part of the Tasmania onto the world stage.

Congratulations to everyone that cuddled the Cardigan in 2025 and made that day in May so memorable.

Thanks for capturing the action@JasperdaSeymour !
 Put this on the big screen and enjoy.

Thumbnail Image thanks to Beard McBeard's clever eye.

videos.title: Coast to Coast | Crossing Tasmania
videos.description: Join Alex Lack as he attempts @PaysonMcElveen FKT, traversing across Tasmania from Arthurs River on the west coast to Binalong Bay on the east coast of the state. Follow him as he tackles the brutal climbs and stunning views that Tasmania has to offer.

videos.title: The Devils Cardigan 2024 - UCI Gravel World Series
videos.description:
In 2023 and 2024, The Devils Cardigan 
proudly hosted the AusCycling Gravel 
National Championships in Tasmania. 

In 2025, it’s time for Tassie to take on the world!

We are excited to share that the Devils Cardigan has joined the
UCI Gravel World Series Family.

We Join Seven Gravel Race and Gravelista in Australia as a qualifying pathway to the 
UCI World Gravel Championships. 

So my gravel minions, mark the dates below on your Calendar. 

Subscribe to our Channel follow us on our social channels and remember, 
you’re not here for a shoe shine.
This is The Devils Cardigan.

quotes.text: It was so much harder than last year. I don't know why. And quite a few guys were very nice on climbs of a take me going job and that's actually really the camaraderie from all the riders is just amazing. So yeah, I got a good boost for kind of midsection of the route.
It's been a been a bit of a sucker fest out there today. There's way too much uphill in this course. I think it should be revised.
It was a day of hot racing despite the frosty winter start, the 106 km Championship course delivered 2400m of elevation with a spicy range of gravel surfaces.

key_challenges.name: Snake Pit
key_challenges.description: Lots of trees and stuff over and really wet. It's like a river bed with soft gravel, soft mud and water. Bike pretty much got stuck. It's fun but hard and slow.

key_challenges.name: Warar to Delerain section
key_challenges.description: Mix of fire road and into some pretty gnarly like rough terrain. Some walking required. Probably wouldn't even do it on a mountain bike. Lots of steep climbs. The climbs felt longer in the dark when you can't see the top.

terrain_notes.text: Snake pit section has soft gravel, soft mud and water like a river bed. Bikes get stuck in the conditions.
From Warar to Delerain features pretty gnarly rough terrain that's so tough you probably wouldn't even do it on a mountain bike.

race_day_tips.text: Weather can change dramatically - around 4:00 a.m. it got really cold and started raining, forcing riders to make difficult decisions about continuing.
Bring multiple bike lights - one rider's first axis battery went flat after only 7 hours when it shouldn't, and the replacement only lasted 4 hours.
The course was much harder than the previous year according to finishers, so expect increased difficulty.

additional_quotes.text: The camaraderie from all the riders is just amazing. Quite a few guys were very nice on climbs giving me encouragement and that's actually really what got me a good boost for the midsection of the route.
You definitely feel like you're out there by yourself and there's no one else around. Just you and that's an interesting feeling.

rider_intel.search_text: The Devils Cardigan features extremely challenging terrain including the notorious Snake Pit section, described as a river bed with soft gravel, soft mud and water where bikes get stuck. The course runs from Arthur's river to Warar, with particularly gnarly rough terrain from Warar to Delerain that requires walking and features steep climbs so difficult riders say they wouldn't attempt them on mountain bikes. Weather conditions can change dramatically, with temperatures dropping and rain starting around 4 a.m. Equipment reliability is crucial as bike lights can fail unexpectedly. The course was reportedly much harder than previous years. Despite the brutal conditions, riders emphasize the strong community spirit and camaraderie, with fellow competitors providing encouragement during difficult climbs. The race leaves participants feeling isolated in remote wilderness sections but also creates lasting bonds through shared suffering.

photos.alt: Aerial view of gravel cyclists riding single file on rural dirt road surrounded by lush green vegetation and trees - Devils Cardigan - Tasmania, Australia
Black and white finish line moment with cyclist raising arm in victory while crossing gravel race finish with spectators and banners - Devils Cardigan - Tasmania, Australia
Close-up of hand holding amber beer glass in indoor setting with warm bokeh lighting in background - Devils Cardigan - Tasmania, Australia
Course preview from Devils Cardigan race footage
